markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1981 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR POINTE AUX CHENES SOUTH OF THE SAULT STE MARIE ONTARIO AIRPORT ON THE SHORELINE OF THE ST MARYS RIVER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF DES CHENES DRIVE AND POINTE AUX PINS ROAD SOUTH OF THE AIRPORT, GO SOUTH AND WEST ON DES CHENES DRIVE FOR 1.9 KILOMETERS(1.2 MILES) TO THE DRIVEWAY AT 311 DES CHENES DRIVE ON THE LEFT. THE ROD IS CEMENTED INTO A 2 1/2 INCH PIPE WHICH IS DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.31 METERS. WRIGHT  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN SAULT STE MARIE MI, GO WEST FOR 1.0 KM (0.65 MI) ON RIDGE STREET, TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH FOR  0.3 KM (0.2 MI) ON MERIDIAN STREET TO INTERSECTION OF MERIDIAN STREET AND SOUTH STREET, TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST FOR 1.0 KM (0.6 MI) ON A GRAVEL ROAD TO ASHMUN BAY BOAT LAUNCH.  TRAVEL BY BOAT UPRIVER FOR 0.75 HOURS PAST RED AND WHITE NAVIGATION LIGHT (PT. LOUISE) AND STATION UNDER LARGE WHITE NAVIGATION TRIPOD.  THE STATION IS A 1 CM (2 IN) PIPE FILLED WITH CONCRETE CENTER MARKED WITH A SQUARE BOLT.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.8 METERS ABOVE THE MARK.

BEAR WEST-NORTHWEST FOR 0.4 KM (0.2 MI) ALONG THE WATERWAY TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1878 ON THE SW END OF EVERENS POINT ON WESTERN ST JOSEPH ISLAND, AT THE POINT WHERE THE MUNUSCONG CHANNEL ENTERS LAKE MUNUSCONG.  IT IS 40 FEET FROM THE POINT, 20 FEET FROM MUNSCONG CHANNEL TO THE W, AND 40 FEET TO LAKE MUNUSCONG TO THE SE.  THERE ARE OUTCROPPING ROCKS 6 FEET S OF THE STATION AND ALSO 6 FEET W.  A WIRE LINE FENCE IS 2 FEET NW OF THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A 3/4-INCH DRILL HOLE IN A SMOOTH ROCK 20 INCHES UNDERGROUND.  A STANDARD I B C BRONZE DISK SET IN A 7-INCH CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 20 INCHES LONG IS SET OVER THE STATION, PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND IN A CAIRN.  THIS REPLACED A PARTLY ROTTED CEDAR POST FOUND OVER THE STATION.  A TRIPOD PAINTED WHITE IS OVER THE STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1968)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1968 RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1988 (RAB) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 34.3 KM (21.3 MI) SOUTHEAST OF SAULT STE MARIE, 38.6 KM (24.0 MI) EAST OF RUDYARD, 29.8 KM (18.5 MI) NORTH-NORTHWEST OF DETOUR VILLAGE IN PART OF LOT 17, NEEBISH CONCESSION IN THE TOWNSHIP OF ST JOSEPH. OWNERSHIP---TOWNSHIP OF ST. JOSEPH, ONTARIO, CANADA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN BARBEAU MI, GO EAST FOR 4.4 KM (2.7 MI) ON 15 MILE ROAD T0 SCENIC DRIVE, TURN RIGHT AND GO SOUTH FOR 6.3 KM (3.9 MI) ON SCENIC DRIVE TO JENS RESORT. TRAVEL BY BOAT DOWNRIVER FOR 15 MINUTES TO A POINT OF LAND CALLED WINTER POINT, GO EAST FOR 15 MINUTES TO THE MUNUSCONG CHANNEL, TRAVEL ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE CHANNEL WHERE THE CHANNEL BECOMES MUNUSCONG LAKE AND EVERENS POINT WHERE THE STATION IS LOCATED.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT AND SURROUNDED BY ROCK.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.8 METERS ABOVE THE MARK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1988 (PBW) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AT THIS DATE. THE CURRENT DESCRIPTION IS ADEQUATE.  THE STATIONS GEODETIC POSITION WAS VERIFIED AT THIS TIME. HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.50 METERS ABOVE THE MARK. RECOVERED BY P B WALBOLT.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY ONTARIO POWER GENERATION 2008 THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 12.4 KM (7.7 MI) NORTHEAST OF MASSENA, 4.6 KM (2.9 MI) WEST-SOUTHWEST OF CORNWALL, CANADA AND 0.5 KM (0.3 MI) NORTHEAST OF THE MOSES-SAUNDERS DAM OWNERSHIP ONTARIO POWER GENERATION.  CONTACT THE ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT AT 613-932-3072 TO OBTAIN PERMISSION TO ACCESS THE MARK.   TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF STATE HIGHWAYS 37 AND 131, GO NORTHERLY ON HIGHWAY 131 (BARNHART ISLE ROAD) FOR 3.6 KM (2.2 MI) TO THE TUNNEL AT THE EISENHOWER LOCK.  PASS THROUGH THE TUNNEL AND CONTINUE NORTHERLY FOR 1.45 KM (0.9 MI) TO A CROSSROAD.  CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 1.1 KM (0.7 MI) TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT (BEACH MARINA ROAD). CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 2.85 KM (1.8 MI) TO THE PASNY SECURITY BUILDING ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE AHEAD FOR 1.15 KM (0.7 MI) TO THE DAM GO NORTHWEST ON THE DAM FOR 0.95 KM (0.6 MI) TO THE NORTHEAST END OF THE DAM PROCEED NORTHEAST AND ALONG THE ACCESS ROAD FOR 0.4 KM (0.2 MI) TO THE SECURITY GATE.  PASS THROUGH THE GATE AND CONTINUE NORTHEAST FOR 0.15 KM (0.1 MI) ALONG THE ROAD AND ACROSS A WATERWAY TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT.
markers.stability: PROBABLY HOLD POSITION/ELEVATION WELL

STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE NORTHEAST SIDE OF NAVY ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 190 AND WEST RIVER ROAD ON GRAND ISLAND, THIS IS THE MOST NORTHERLY INTERCHANGE ON GRAND ISLAND, GO WEST ON WEST RIVER ROAD FOR 0.35 MILE TO A PUMPING STATION ON THE RIGHT.  FROM THE PUMPING STATION, TAKE A BOAT ON A MAGNETIC BEARING OF N50W FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE NORTHEAST SIDE OF NAVY ISLAND AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK IS A 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER BRASS PLUG, SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THE IS 2 FEET BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 94 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE RIVER BANK AND 63 FEET SOUTH OF A BLACK LOCUST TREE WITH A TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  THIS STATION IS ON PROPERTY ADMINISTERED BY THE NIAGARA PARKS COMMISSION.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM THEM BEFORE USING THIS STATION.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1957 (WNM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THERE WAS NO OLD DESCRIPTION AVAILABLE. REFERENCE MARKS 1 AND 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS-  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MI. S OF AMHERSTBURG, AT SUMMIT BEACH ON BAR POINT, ON THE N SHORE OF LAKE ERIE, AT THE MOUTH OF THE DETROIT RIVER.  IT IS 4 FT. W OF THE W EDGE OF A CONCRETE SEAWALL, 4 FT. NW OF THE W END OF AN E-W SEAWALL, AND 70 FT. SW OF THE SW CORNER OF A FRAMEHOUSE.  THE STATION IS AN X IN A 1-IN. STEEL ROD, IN THE CENTER OF AN 18-IN. DIAMETER CONCRETE CYLINDER PROJECTING ABOUT 6 IN. ABOVE A CONCRETE PIER THAT SUPPORTS A PERMANENT 15-FT. WOODEN STAND.  THE CONCRETE CYLINDER IS INSCRIBED USLS BAR POINT 1877.  PART OF THE INSCRIPTION IS NOT LEGIBLE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE FEDERAL BUILDING IN AMHERSTBURG, GO W ON HIGHWAY 18 (RICHMOND STREET) FOR 0.05 MI.  TURN LEFT AND GO S ON HIGHWAY 18 (DALHOUSIE STREET) FOR 2.95 MI. TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT (THIS IS WHERE HIGHWAY 18 TURNS E).  TURN RIGHT AND GO S ON THE PAVED ROAD FOR 0.5 MI. TO FRANCIS SCOTT DRIVE RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO W ON FRANCIS SCOTT DRIVE FOR 0.1 MI. TO THE END OF THE DRIVE.  WALK SW AROUND THE FRAMEHOUSE TO THE STATION IN THE SW EDGE OF THE LAWN.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS 0.8 FT. E OF THE W EDGE OF A CONCRETE SEAWALL, 28 FT. N OF THE W END OF AN E-W SEAWALL, 46 FT. W OF THE SW CORNER OF THE FRAMEHOUSE, AND 9 FT. W OF AN 18-IN. WILLOW TREE. THE DISK IS SET FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE SEAWALL AND IS STAMPED BAR POINT USLS NO 1 1957.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SET IN A CONCRETE SEAWALL, 6 FT. S OF THE S EDGE OF THE CONCRETE STEPS THAT LEAD TO THE BEACH, 16 FT. W OF AN 18-IN. WALNUT TREE, 67 FT. NW OF THE NW CORNER OF A FRAME CABIN, AND 56 FT. S OF THE E END OF THE E-W SEAWALL.  THE DISK IS SET FLUSH IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE SEAWALL AND IS STAMPED BAR POINT USLS NO 2 1957.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK - 5 METERS.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1943 (JH) STATION IS 1/4 MILE E OF THE MOUTH OF GARDEN RIVER AND N OF PAYMENT CHURCH, ON E SIDE OF ROAD RIGHT - OF - WAY LEADING TO RIVER.  IT IS 4.5 FEET W OF FENCE, 140 FEET S OF CORNER POST AT INTERSECTION OF E - AND - W ROAD, AT TOP OF BANK, ABOUT 150 FEET BACK FROM WATER, AND 12 FEET ABOVE.  IT IS 4.7 FEET FROM LARGE FENCE POST AT TOP OF BANK AND 6.4 FEET FROM NEXT POST N.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD I B C BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK IN A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 20 INCHES LONG SET FLUSH WITH SURFACE OF GROUND.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A ROUND-HEADED COPPER RIVET IN A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 10 INCHES LONG SET 2 FEET UNDERGROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

THE STATION INTERSECTED WAS THE HIGHEST VERTICAL POINT OF THE LIGHT ATOP THE SQUARE SKELTAL TOWER WHICH HAS AN ORANGE TRIANGULAR DAYMARK WITH BLACK VERTICAL STRIPES.  DESCRIBED BY M JOHNSON.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1985 (MWJ) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTH END OF BAYFIELD ISLAND IN ONTARIO, CANADA.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM CAPE VINCENT, NEW YORK GO BY BOAT DUE NORTH FOR APPROXIMATELY FOUR MILES TO THE SOUTH END OF BAYFIELD ISLAND AND THE AREA OF THE STATION.  PERMISSION MAY BE REQUIRED BY THE CANADIAN AUTHORITIES TO SURVEY IN THIS AREA.  THE STATION IS AN ALUMINUM ROD EMBEDDED IN CONCRETE FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  THE STATION IS A CHISLED X IN THE CENTER OF THE ROD. IT IS LOCATED 98.8 FEET SSE FROM A 24 INCH DIAMETER LONE TREE AND 16.8 FEET NORTH FROM THE SOUTH BLUFF.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.50 METERS ABOVE THE MARK.  DESCRIBED BY M JOHNSON.

MARKED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA BRONZE DISK IN SOLID ROCK.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE ARROWS CUT IN SOLID ROCK. TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CUSTOMS OFFICE ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE IN SAULT STE MARIE, CANADA, GO SOUTH ON HURON STREET TO ITS JUNCTION WITH QUEEN STREET. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1921 (JSB) ON LAKE OF THE WOODS, ON SOUTHWEST POINT OF BIG ISLAND, AND ON BARE ROCK ABOUT 3-1/2 METERS (11 FEET) ABOVE LAKE LEVEL.  GROWTH OF LARGE HARDWOOD TIMBER IS BACK OF ROCK.  MARKED BY STANDARD BRONZE DISK OF INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION IN SOLID ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (GCR) THE STATION WAS VISITED AND THE MARK RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION. THE STATION WAS NOT OCCUPIED AT THIS TIME.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED 27 MILES EAST AND 12 MILES NORTH OF WARROAD, MINNESOTA ON BASIL POINT WHICH FORMS THE EXTREME SOUTHWEST TIP OF BIG ISLAND, 30 FEET SOUTH OF THE HIGHEST POINT OF ROCK, ABOUT 15 FEET ABOVE THE LEVEL OF THE LAKE, AND AT THE CENTER OF A TRIANGLE FORMED BY THREE SIX INCH HOLES, OUTLINED BY CONCRETE, THAT WERE THE LEG BASES OF THE OLD TOWER.  THE MARK IS A 2-INCH BRONZE DISK, WITH THE LETTERS U S AND C B SURVEY AND A SMALL TRIANGLE CAST THEREIN, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK 3 INCHES BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  A RING OF ROCKS 18 INCHES HIGH WAS PLACED AROUND THE MARK.  THE STATION WAS REACHED BY FLOAT PLANE FROM WARROAD.  THE PLANE WAS BEACHED IN A SMALL SANDY COVE JUST NORTH OF THE POINT, AND THE STATION PACKED TO BY WALKING SOUTH ALONG THE SHORE LINE TO THE POINT.  ABOUT 10 MINUTES PACK.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1875 ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ON QUEENSTON HEIGHTS.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE MONUMENT AT THE ELEVATION OF THE WINDOW OPENINGS JUST ABOVE THE LANDING AT THE HEAD OF THE STAIRS INSIDE THE MONUMENT.  THE MONUMENT, A MEMORIAL TO GENERAL BROCK, IS A TRIANGULATION STATION OF THE USLS, THE GS OF C, AND THE USC + GS, DIRECTLY CONNECTED WITH THE FIRST - ORDER TRIANGULATION OF THE THREE SYSTEMS.  THE CHAMBER AT THE TOP OF THE MONUMENT IS 4.5 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THE STAIR AND A SEAT OCCUPY ONE - HALF OF THE FLOOR SPACE.  THE CENTER OF THE CHAMBER IS MARKED BY A TACK IN THE WOODEN SEAT.  THE TACK IS 0.1 FOOT FROM THE IRON POST SUPPORTING THE SEAT AND 0.15 FOOT FROM THE STRAIGHT EDGE OF THE SEAT.  THE MASONRY WALLS AT THE CHAMBER ELEVATION ARE 1.15 FEET THICK.  THERE ARE EIGHT WINDOWS IN THE CHAMBER, EQUALLY SPACED AROUND THE TOWER AT AN ELEVATION OF 4.5 FEET ABOVE THE FLOOR.  SEVEN OF THE WINDOWS ARE 0.8 FOOT IN DIAMETER, THE EIGHTH ON IS 1.4 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THE MONUMENT CAN BE OCCUPIED WITH THE TRANSIT BY MAKING ECCENTRIC STATIONS WHERE TWO OR MORE POINTS CAN BE SEEN AT THE SAME TIME THROUGH THE WINDOW OPENINGS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1941 ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ON QUEENSTON HEIGHTS.  THE STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE MONUMENT AT THE ELEVATION OF THE WINDOW OPENINGS JUST ABOVE THE LANDING AT THE HEAD OF THE STAIRS INSIDE THE MONUMENT.  THE MONUMENT, A MEMORIAL TO GENERAL BROCK, IS A TRIANGULATION STATION OF THE U. S. L. S., THE G. S. OF C., AND THE U. S. C. AND G. S., DIRECTLY CONNECTED WITH THE FIRST-ORDER TRIANGULATION OF THE THREE SYSTEMS.  THE CHAMBER AT THE TOP OF THE MONUMENT IS 4.5 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THE STAIR AND A SEAT OCCUPY ONE-HALF OF THE FLOOR SPACE.  THE CENTER OF THE CHAMBER IS MARKED BY A TACK IN THE WOODEN SEAT.  THE TACK IS 0.1 FOOT FROM THE IRON POST SUPPORTING THE SEAT AND 0.15 FOOT FROM THE STRAIGHT EDGE OF THE SEAT.  THE MASONRY WALLS AT THE CHAMBER ELEVATION ARE 1.15 FEET THICK. THERE ARE EIGHT WINDOWS IN THE CHAMBER, EQUALLY SPACED AROUND THE TOWER AT AN ELEVATION OF 4.5 FEET ABOVE THE FLOOR.  SEVEN OF THE WINDOWS ARE 0.8 FOOT IN DIAMETER.  THE EIGHTH ONE IS 1.4 FEET IN DIAMETER.  THE MONUMENT CAN BE OCCUPIED WITH THE TRANSIT BY MAKING ECCENTRIC STATIONS WHERE TWO OR MORE POINTS CAN BE SEEN AT THE SAME TIME THROUGH THE WINDOW OPENINGS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (HLM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED.  THE TACK AND WOODEN SEAT MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION IS NO LONGER THERE.  THE MONUMENT WAS UNDER REPAIR AT TIME OF RECOVERY.  DUE TO SCAFFOLDING APPARATUS ON TOP OF THE MONUMENT AND IN THE OBSERVATION ROOM, THE CENTER OF THE ROOM WAS FOUND ON THE SAME LEVEL AS THE BOTTOM OF AN ACCESS WINDOW AND THE TOP OF A METAL PIPE IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE ROOM WHICH IS ABOUT 2 FEET LOWER THAN WHERE CENTER WAS FOUND IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION.  STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES SOUTH OF LEWISTON, NEW YORK, 1/2 MILE NORTHWEST OF THE LEWISTON-QUEENSTON BRIDGE, 1/2 MILE SOUTHEAST OF QUEENSTON, ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ON QUEENSTON HEIGHTS, IN QUEENSTON PARK, IN THE CENTER OF THE OBSERVATION ROOM ATOP BROCKS MONUMENT (A MEMORIAL TO GENERAL BROCK).  PERMISSION TO USE THE MONUMENT WAS OBTAINED THROUGH MR. WALTER HALDERSON, SUPERINTENDENT, NIAGARA NATIONAL HISTORIC SITES, POST OFFICE BOX 787, NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, ONTARIO.  STATION IS THE CENTER OF THE OBSERVATION ROOM WHICH IS 0.005 METERS EAST OF A PUNCH HOLE IN TOP OF THE METAL PIPE.  A TAPE MEASUREMENT WAS MADE TO BROCKS MONUMENT REFERENCE POINT, THE DISTANCE BEING 5.450 FEET OR 1.663 METERS.  A TRAVERSE MEASUREMENT WAS MADE TO BROCK ECC, THE DISTANCE BEING (5.76 FEET) OR 1.7562 METERS.  FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON BROCKS MONUMENT REFERENCE POINT AND BROCK ECC REFER TO THE DESCRIPTION TO STATION BROCKS MONUMENT REFERENCE POINT.  NOTE--CENTER OF THE OBSERVATION ROOM WAS DETERMINED BY MEASURING THE CIRCUMFERENCE.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN 1/2 MILE SOUTHEAST OF QUEENSTON, ONTARIO, CANADA.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE BOUNDARY, ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF NAVY ISLAND IN THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 100 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH END OF THE RUINS OF AN OLD DOCK.  THE STATION IS AT THE EDGE OF THE RIVER BANK WHICH IS RAPIDLY BREAKING DOWN AND THERE IS DANGER THAT THE STATION WILL SOON BE GONE.  FOR THIS REASON IT WAS PERMANENTLY REFERENCED IN 1941.  THE STATION IS 70 FEET NORTH OF A 7 - INCH ELM, 46 FEET SOUTH OF A 20 - INCH OAK, AND 76 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A 26 - INCH OAK. REFERENCE NO 2 (REFERRED TO IN THE FIELD NOTES AS---CAMP-1941---) IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK SHOWING 15 BY 15 INCHES FLUSH WITH THE GROUND 28 FEET FROM THE HIGH BANK OF THE RIVER IN A LITTLE CLEARING NEAR THE APPROACH TO THE OLD DOCK AND 67.7 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A 3 - FOOT OAK TREE. DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) ON THE W SIDE OF COCKBURN ISLAND, ON THE POINT S OF THE INDIAN VILLAGE, AND BETWEEN THE TWO BRANCHES OF THE LARGE BAY ON THE E SIDE OF FALSE DETOUR CHANNEL.  IT IS ABOUT 200 FEET S OF THE EXTREME END OF THIS POINT AND ACROSS A TINY BAY FROM THIS POINT.  IT IS ABOUT 25 FEET OUTSIDE THE TREE LINE AND TWICE THIS DISTANCE FROM THE WATER. REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A BRASS RIVET WITH THE SMALL END PROJECTING FROM A CONCRETE BLOCK 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 10 INCHES LONG SET WITH THE TOP 8 INCHES OUT OF THE GROUND IN A LARGE CAIRN. REFERENCE MARK 3 IS A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK 1 BY 1 FOOT BY 8 INCHES HIGH, SW OF THE STATION, AND 4 FEET OUTSIDE THE TREE LINE.  IT IS 30.57 FEET FROM THE STATION.

STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1969 (CWB) SURFACE MARK WAS FOUND OUT OF GROUND ON ITS SIDE NEAR STATION. SUBSURFACE MARK WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION, AS WAS THE REFERENCE MARK.  DUE TO VARIOUS CHANGES A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS. ON THE RIGHT OF WAY OF THE CN RAILWAY.  TO REACH STATION FROM CN RAILWAY STATION IN RAINY RIVER, ONT., GO E ON ONT. HIGHWAY 11 FOR 1.7 MILES, THEN TURN N ON DRIVE TO MR. NORMAN MARTINSONS HOUSE AND GO 0.02 MILES TO CN RAILWAYS TRACKS, WITH STATION AND REFERENCE MARK ON THE WEST.  THE STATION IS 267.5 FEET E ALONG THE TRACKS, WHERE BOTTLE CAP AND NAIL ARE IN THE TIE, FROM MILEPOST 142, 21.9 FEET W FROM CENTER OF DRIVE, AND 6.8 FEET S FROM CENTER OF S RAIL AT POINT WHERE BOTTLE CAP AND NAIL ARE IN TIE. MARIE, ON THE HIGHEST HILL IN THE VICINITY, ABOUT 3/8 MILE WEST-NORTHWEST OF THE SOUTHEAST SECTION CORNER, 29.59 FEET S 48 DEG 00 MIN W (TRUE) OF REFERENCE NO. 1 (DESCRIBED BELOW), 25.19 FEET S 32 DEG 10 MIN E (TRUE) OF REFERENCE NO. 2 (DESCRIBED BELOW), MARKED AT THE SURFACE BY A 5/8 INCH DRILL HOLE, 1 INCH DEEP, AT THE SOUTH SIDE OF A ROUGH CONCAVITY IN SURFACE ROCK, UNDER AN OLD, (1895), 21 FOOT CEDAR TRIPOD. MARIE, WEST ALONG A DIRT ROAD 1.2 MILES TO A CROSSROAD.  THENCE LEFT 1.6 MILES TO A JUNCTION WITH ROAD TO GOULAIS RIVER BRIDGE.  THENCE RIGHT 1.4 MILES TO ANOTHER JUNCTION.  THENCE RIGHT 3.2 MILES TO A LOGGING ROAD RIGHT. THENCE ALONG LOGGING ROAD 1.5 MILES TO CREST OF A HILL (ROAD IS BEST NAVIGATED BY TRUCK OR JEEP IN DRY WEATHER). THENCE ALONG RIGHT BRANCH WHICH IS A SKIDWAY TO A POINT WHERE IT CROSSES A CREEK.  THENCE ALONG CREEK IN A NORTHERLY DIRECTION TO TOWNSHIP LINE RUNNING EAST AND WEST WHICH IS WELL MARKED BY TREES BLAZED THREE TIMES AROUND CIRCUMFERENCE.  THENCE WEST ALONG TOWNSHIP LINE OVER A LOW RIDGE TO A CREEK.  THENCE CROSS CREEK AND WALK NORTH TO THE STATION.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ABOUT 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF PINEWOOD, AT CURVE OF CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY, 552 METERS (1,811 FEET) WEST OF MILEPOST 133, ON EXTENSION OF SOUTH RAIL FROM WEST, AND 3.212 METERS (10.54 FEET) SOUTH OF EXTENSION OF NORTH RAIL FROM EAST.  SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE STANDARD STATION DISKS IN CONCRETE. REFERENCE MARK IS STANDARD REFERENCE DISK IN CONCRETE, 11.385 METERS (37.35 FEET) FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (LMC) STATION WAS RECOVERED AND THE REFERENCE MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE SURFACE STATION MARK WAS FOUND BROKEN OFF ABOUT 8 INCHES BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  A NEW SURFACE MARK WAS ESTABLISHED DIRECTLY OVER THE UNDERGROUND MARK.  AN AZIMUTH MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME. THE DISTANCE TO THE REFERENCE MARK DID NOT CHECK.  DUE TO VARIOUS CHANGES A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 11 MILES EAST OF BAUDETTE, MINNESOTA, 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF PINEWOOD, 1/2 MILE NORTH OF KINGS HIGHWAY 11 AND ON PROPERTY OF MR. DAN CARROL.  TO REACH FROM THE DEPOT IN RAINY RIVER, GO EAST ON KINGS HIGHWAY 11 FOR 10.75 MILES TO LAUZON ROAD ON THE LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON LAUZON ROAD FOR 0.55 MILE TO CROSSROAD JUST AFTER CROSSING RAILROAD TRACK, TURN LEFT AND GO WESTERLY FOLLOWING ROAD FOR 0.3 MILE, THENCE NORTH FOLLOWING ROAD FOR 0.1 MILE TO MR CARROLS HOUSE ON LEFT AND BARN YARD TO THE NORTH OF HOUSE, PASS THROUGH GATE INTO BARN YARD, TURN LEFT AND GO WEST 200 FEET TO THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF BARN YARD AND OPENING IN FENCE.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM HERE, TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTH ACROSS PASTURE FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF PASTURE AND MARK AS DESCRIBED.) GO WEST-SOUTHWEST ACROSS PASTURE FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF PASTURE AND STATION AS DESCRIBED.  ALL MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE POSTS.  STATION MARK, STAMPED HENRI 1923 1967, IS SET FLUSH.  IT IS 185 FEET NORTHWEST OF A WHISTLE POST, 59 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL OF RAILROAD TRACK, 12 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE FENCE CORNER, 5.5 FEET NORTH OF A EAST-WEST FENCE AND 5.1 FEET EAST-NORTHEAST OF THE WITNESS POST.  REFERENCE MARK, STAMPED HENRI 1923, IS SET 2 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE.  IT IS 49 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL OF RAILROAD TRACKS, 41.3 FEET EAST OF THE WITNESS POST, 40 FEET EAST OF THE FENCE CORNER AND 1 FOOT NORTH OF A EAST-WEST FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 2, STAMPED HENRI 1923 NO 2 1967, PROJECTS 3 INCHES. IT IS 2 FEET SOUTH OF WITNESS POST AND 1 FOOT EAST OF NORTH-SOUTH FENCE.  AZIMUTH MARK, STAMPED HENRI 1923 1967, PROJECTS 3 INCHES.  IT IS 115.5 FEET WEST OF THE NORTHEAST FENCE CORNER OF PASTURE, 2 FEET SOUTH OF THE FENCE AND 2 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE WITNESS POST.  NOTICE--A 4-WHEEL DRIVE IS NEEDED IN WET WEATHER TO GET THROUGH THE BARN YARD.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 113 FEET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--2-1/2 MILES WEST OF RAINY RIVER                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1969 (CWB) THIS STATION WAS PART OF A FIRST ORDER TRAVERSE RAN BY C.M. DURGIN OF USC AND GS IN 1923 AND ALSO PART OF A SECOND ORDER TRIANGULATION SURVEY BY L.M. CHASE IN 1967.  STATION MARK, AZIMUTH MARK, AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1967 DESCRIPTION BY R.P.K. UNDER CHIEF OF PARTY L.M. CHASE (USC AND GS) WAS FOUND TO BE GOOD, EXCEPT THAT THE AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN SHOULD READ 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF PINEWOOD, ONT. INSTEAD OF 2-1/2 MILES WEST OF RAINY RIVER. STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1975 (JDS) THE STATION MARK, REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 AND THE AZIMUTH MARK WERE RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION AS DESCRIBED BY L.M. CHASE IN 1967.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 APPEARS TO BE SLIGHTLY TILTED WITH THE NORTH SIDE OF THE MARK A LITTLE HIGHER THAN THE SOUTH SIDE. A DIFFERENCE OF 3 MINUTES AND 44 SECONDS WAS FOUND IN THE DIRECTION TO REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 1 AND DIFFERENCES OF 0.03 FOOT AND 0.011 METER IN THE DISTANCE TO THE MARK.  THE STATION MARK WAS USED AS THE ANTENNA SITE FOR THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA SOPPLER STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NUMBER 2 WAS USED AS THE ANTENNA SITE FOR GEOCEIVER STATION 51102.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3 MILES WEST OF PINEWOOD.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) ON THE NW POINT OF KITCHENER ISLAND AT THE S ENTRANCE TO FALSE DETOUR CHANNEL FROM LAKE HURON.  IT IS IN OPEN GROUND ABOUT 100 FEET FROM THE EXTREME END OF THE POINT, 30 FEET INSIDE THE TAMARACK TREES ON THE POINT, 47 FEET FROM THE WATER ON THE E SIDE OF THE POINT, AND 20 FEET INSIDE THE SMALL TREE ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BEACH ON E SIDE OF POINT.  AN ECCENTRIC STATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE TOP OF A TALL CEDAR TREE S OF THE STATION, IN THE EDGE OF THE WOODS.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE I B C DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A SOLID ROCK SHOWING 2 FEET BY 2 FEET BY 5 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE DRILL HOLES IN ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS IN A SANDSTONE ROCK ON THE BEACH E OF THE STATION, ABOUT 125 FEET E OF THE POINT.  ROCK IS 4 BY 3 FEET BY 2 FEET HIGH AND IS ONE OF A GROUP OF LARGE ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS IN A SOLID DARK - COLORED ROCK S OF THE STATION, SHOWING 2 FEET BY 1 FOOT BY 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  IT IS 40 FEET FROM THE WATER E OF THE POINT.  ROCK IS ONE OF A GROUP OF FOUR ROCKS.  RFERENCE MARK 3 IS IN CENTER OF THE POINT W OF THE STATION, BEING 125 FEET FROM POINT AND ABOUT 100 FEET TO WATER ON EACH SIDE OF THE POINT.  IT IS IN A LARGE OPEN SPACE, IN A ROCK 30 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.

IT IS 15 FEET S OF EDGE OF CONCRETE PAYMENT OF HIGHWAY, 100 FEET N OF TOP OF RIVER BANK, ABOUT 120 FEET BACK FROM WATER, AND 15 FEET ABOVE.  IT IS ABOUT 15 FEET E OF POINT OPPOSITE A SMALL DRAW IN RIVER BANK, 104.5 FEET SSE OF W GATEPOST, 97.4 FEET SE OF TELEPHONE POLE, 69.8 FEET SW OF TELEPHONE POLE, AND 191.7 FEE ESE OF IRON POST NO 154 ON N SIDE OF HIGHWAY.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD I B C BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK IN TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 20 INCHES LONG SET 2 INCHES BELOW SURFACE OF GROUND.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A 3/4-INCH DRILL HOLE 1 INCH DEEP INSCRIBED WITH A SQUARE AND---XIV---CUT IN SURFACE OF FLAT LIMESTONE SET 2 FEET BELOW SURFACE OF GROUND.  THIS STONE WAS ORIGINAL U S LAKE SURVEY STATION MARK FOUND LYING ON SLOPE OF RIVER BANK WHERE IT WAS LEFT BY BANK EROSION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

IT IS IN OPEN GROUND, ON A HIGH RIDGE ABOUT 1/3 OF THE WAY DOWN THE ISLAND FROM THE N END, AND MIDWAY BETWEEN E AND W SHORES.  STATION MARK IS A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK UNDERGROUND.  A STANDARD U S L S BRONZE DISK WITH A CROSE AND---KOCRUISH---STAMPED ON IT, IN A 6-INCH CONCRETE CYLINDER, IS SET OVER THE STATION WITH ITS TOP 8 INCHES ABOVE GROUND IN A CAIRN.  A 30-FOOT POLE WAS WIRED UP OVER THE STATION.  A 24-FOOT TOWER WAS BUILT OVER THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE CROSSES CUT ON ROCKS.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ON A HIGH PINKISH BOULDER 9 BY 8 FEET BY 3 FEET HIGH, DISTANT 70.95 FEET SE OF THE STATION, ON SLIGHTLY LOWER GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS ON A WHITE ROCK 6 BY 6 FEET BY 5 FEET HIGH, DISTANT 53.22 FEET SW OF THE STATION, ON THE SAME RIDGE, IN A THICKET OF YOUNG TREES.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCES O K TOWER IS STILL STANDING.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1894 ABOUT 3 MILES EAST OF LAKE GEORGE, ABOUT IN CENTER OF SECTION 16, LAIRD TOWNSHIP, ABOUT 1/2 MILE EAST OF ROAD TO ECOBA, 1/2 MILE SOUTH OF HOUSE OWNED BY MR. RILLEY, AND ON SOLID ROCK HILL.  MARKED BY CROSS CUT IN SOLID ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1949)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US LAKE SURVEY 1949 A PRIMARY STATION, IN NEAR THE CENTER OF SECTION 16, LAIRD TOWNSHIP, ALGOMA DISTRICT ONTARIO, CANADA, ABOUT 6 MILES SOUTHEAST OF ECHO BAY, ABOUT 1-1/2 MILES EAST OF KINGS HIGHWAY 17, ON THE NORTHEAST CORNER AND HIGHEST POINT OF A STEEP-SIDED ROCK HILL (ELEVATION BY TRIGONOMETRIC LEVELING, 923 FEET), 21.97 FEET S 32 DEG.  03 MIN. W (TRUE) OF REFERENCE NO. 1 (DESCRIBED BELOW), 31.66 FEET N 55 DEG. 41 MIN. W (TRUE) OF REFERENCE NO. 2 (DESCRIBED BELOW), 27.57 FEET S 56 DEG. 52 MIN. E (TRUE) OF REFERENCE NO. 3 (DESCRIBED BELOW), MARKED AT THE SURFACE BY A BRONZE DISC OF THE CANADIAN GEODETIC SURVEY IN THE TOP OF 15 INCH SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT, 8 INCHES HIGH, SET OVER THE OLD MARK WHICH WAS A 1/2 INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE ROCK.  REFERENCE NO. 1, (1894), IS THE INTERSECTION OF A CROSS-LINE ON A 6 INCH ARROW WHICH POINTS TO THE STATION AND IS CUT IN BED ROCK.  REFERENCE NO. 2 (1894), IS THE INTERSECTION OF A CROSS-LINE ON A 6 INCH ARROW WHICH POINTS TO THE STATION AND IS CUT IN BED ROCK.  REFERENCE NO. 3, (1894), IS THE INTERSECTION OF A CROSS-LINE ON A 6 INCH ARROW WHICH POINTS TO THE STATION AND IS CUT IN BED ROCK.  TO REACH THE REFERENCES AND THE STATION PROCEED, FROM THE JUNCTION OF KINGS HIGHWAY 17 AND THE MAIN STREET OF ECHO BAY, SOUTH ALONG 17 6.1 MILES TO A CROSS ROAD (CALLED BRADSHAW CORNER), THENCE EAST 1.0 MILES TO A CROSS ROAD, THENCE NORTH 0.4 MILE TO THE NORTH SIDE OF AN OPEN FIELD, THENCE EAST ALONG NORTH EDGE OF FIELD TO THE FAR CORNER, JOGGING TO THE SOUTH THREE TIMES, THENCE NORTHEAST THROUGH A WOODED AREA UP THE WEST SLOPE OF A ROCK HILL TO THE HIGHEST POINT NEAR THE NORTHEAST CORNER AND THE STATION.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN - 3 MILES EAST OF LAKE GEORGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) TO REACH THIS STATION, PROCEED 5 MILES S FROM ECHO BAY VILLAGE ON THE CONCRETE HIGHWAY, TURN LEFT 1 MILE TO LAIRD CORNERS, AND N 1/2 MILE TO A LARGE OPEN FIELD ON THE E SIDE.  TRAVEL E TO THE EXTREME END OF THIS FIELD AND ACROSS A NARROW STRIP OF WOODS TO THE SW CORNER OF THE HILL ON WHICH THE STATION IS LOCATED.  IT IS ON THE E END OF THE CENTRAL AND HIGHEST OF THE RIDGES ON TOP OF THE SOLID ROCK HILL, AND IN THE CENTER OF A HUGE CAIRN USED TO SUPPORT THE SIGNAL.  IT IS ABOUT THE CENTER OF SECTION 16 AND ABOUT 3 MILES E OF LAKE GEORGE.  UNDER THE CAIRN WILL BE FOUND A TRIANGULAR HOLE IN THE BARE ROCK, ABOUT A FOOT ON A SIDE AND SEVERAL INCHES DEEP WITH A RAISED AND SLOPING TONGUE NEAR THE CENTER.  STATION MARK IS A DRILL HOLE BETWEEN THE LETTERS---U.---AND---S.---ON THE N SLOPE OF THE TONGUE IN CENTER OF THE TRIANGULAR HOLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1988)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1988 (RAB) THE DESIGNATED MARK WAS RECOVERED AS PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED.
markers.stability: MOST RELIABLE AND EXPECTED TO HOLDPOSITION/ELEVATION WELL

HILL IS TIMBERED WITH JACK PINE AND SPRUCE, AND A FEW BIRCH AND POPLAR.  MARKED BY COPPER BOLT STAMPED G.S.C. 1915 IN SOLID OUTCROP OF GRAY GRANITE. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1912 IN MACGREGOR TOWNSHIP, ABOUT 7 MILES NORTHWEST OF MACKENZIE STATION ON THE CANADIAN PACIFIC RAILWAY, ON A ROCK OUTCROP ON THE HIGHEST PART OF A HILL WITH SLIGHTLY WOODED SIDES. IT IS BEST REACHED BY FOLLOWING THE TRACK WESTWARD TO WHERE A WATER PIPE, COVERED BY A DUMP OF SAND 10 FEET HIGH, JOINS THE RIGHT OF WAY.  THENCE FOLLOWING THE PIPE 1-1/4 MILES TO A DAM, AND FROM A PLACE ON THE STREAM 100 METERS WEST OF THE DAM FOLLOWING A TRAIL, ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES LONG, TO THE STATION.  STATION MARK--A COPPER BOLT STAMPED G.S.C. 1912, SET IN SOLID ROCK.  THREE REFERENCE BOLTS ARE SET AS FOLLOWS--NO. 1, N 00 DEG 29 MIN E, DISTANCE 18.64 METERS.  NO. 2, S 37 DEG 25 MIN E, DISTANCE 14.37 METERS.  NO. 3, S 00 DEG 29 MIN W, DISTANCE 11.31 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1972)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1972 (UNK) THE MARK IS LOCATED ABOUT 187.1 KM (116.3 MI) EAST OF ATIKOKAN, 149.5 KM (92.9 MI) WEST OF TERRACE BAY, 79.5 KM (49.4 MI) SOUTHWEST OF NIPIGON AND 19.7 KM (12.2 MI) NORTH-NORTHEAST OF THUNDER BAY.  LOCATION IS ON THE HIGHEST HILL BETWEEN TEA LAKE AND PENASSEN LAKE (KNOWN LOCALLY AS MCGREGOR LAKE).  THERE WAS A HELICOPTER AREA IN 1972 JUST WEST OF THE MONUMENT, ON THE EDGE OF A SHARP CLIFF.  THE MARK IS BY A 2.5 CM (1 INCH) COPPER BOLT WITH A TRIANGULATION MARK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  A SIGN POST IS ABOUT 1.2 M (3.9 FT) EAST OF THE STATION.  LINES TO STATIONS MCKAY AND BOWKER ARE VISIBLE.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 ON RAINY LAKE, ABOUT 26 MILES EAST OF RANIER, MINN., ABOUT 5 MILES EAST OF BRULE NARROWS, AND ON HIGHEST POINT OF LARGE ROCK 100 METERS (328 FEET) SOUTH OF ANCHOR ISLANDS.  MARKED BY STANDARD STATION DISK IN ROCK.  REFERENCE MONUMENT 294 (I. B. C.), MARKED BY STANDARD 8-INCH BRONZE POST OF INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION IN SOLID ROCK, IS 11.89 METERS (39.0 FEET) FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (LMC) THE STATION AND REFERENCE MARK WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK 2 AND AN AZIMUTH MARK WAS ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE HIGHEST POINT OF A LARGE BARE ROCK IN RAINY LAKE, ABOUT 26 MILES EAST OF RANIER, MINNESOTA, U.S.A., 5 MILES EAST-SOUTHEAST OF BURLE NARROWS, 2 MILES NORTH-NORTHEAST OF CAPE RUDOLPH AND 0.3 MILE SOUTH OF ANCHOR ISLANDS.  STATION MARK, IS A TRAVERSE STATION DISK STAMPED MANITOU 1923, CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK.  IT IS 19 FEET WEST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE WATER LINE, 62 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE WATER LINE AND 77 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE WATER.  R.M., IS A 2 X 2 INCH METAL POST SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN OUTCROPPING BEDROCK, PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE AND IS STAMPED INT. BDRY REF. MARK CANADA 294.  IT IS 8 FEET WEST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE WATER LINE, 68 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE WATER AND 80 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE WATER.  R.M. 2, A STANDARD REFERENCE MARK DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK, STAMPED MANITOU NO 2 1923 1967 AND IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE ROCK.  IT IS 1 FOOT EAST OF A 6 FOOT CLIFF, 3 FEET SOUTH OF A SMALL ROCK CAIRN, 28 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ISLAND AND 70 FEET SOUTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ISLAND.  AZ MK, A STANDARD DISK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN BEDROCK, FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE ROCK AND IS STAMPED MANITOU 1923 1967.  IT IS 4.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A ROCK CAIRN, 28 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH EDGE OF THE ISLAND, 58 FEET EAST OF THE WEST EDGE OF THE ISLAND AND 37 FEET SOUTHWEST OF A 14 INCH PINE TREE.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE STATION GO NORTH BY BOAT FOR ABOUT 0.3 MILE TO THE LARGEST ONE OF 3 SMALL ISLANDS AND THE MARK AS DESCRIBED.  NOTE--STATION CAN BE REACHED BY SEA PLANE OR BOAT.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 14 METERS.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) THIS STATION IS ON THE ROUNDING POINT OF COCKBURN ISLAND SOUTH OF THE BAY IN WHICH THE INDIAN VILLAGE IS LOCATED AND NEAR THE CENTER OF THE FALSE DETOUR PASSAGE.  IT IS ON A SOLID OUTCROPPING LEDGE OF LIMESTONE RISING 2 FEET ABOVE THE WATER AND IS 6 FEET BACK FROM EDGE OF THE LEDGE.  A LOWER LEDGE ABOUT 6 FEET WIDE IS JUST AWASH.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE I B C DISK SET IN THE SOLID LIMESTONE LEDGE AND COUNTERSUNK TO PROTECT IT FROM EROSION.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE 3/4-INCH DRILL HOLES 1/2 INCH DEEP IN SOLID ROCK. REFERENCE MARK 1 IS E OF AND 50 FEET UPSTREAM FROM THE STATION AND 45 FEET FROM THE WATER IN A SLOPING ROCK 4 BY 4 FEET BY 2 FEET HIGH. IT IS 15 FEET OUTSIDE THE MAIN WOODS.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SE OF AND DIRECTLY INSHORE FROM THE STATION, AT THE EDGE OF THE WOODS, AND IN A ROCK 5 BY 3 FEET BY 3 FEET HIGH.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS S OF AND ABOUT 125 FEET DOWNSTREAM FROM STATION, IN AN OPEN PLACE 25 FEET FROM THE WATER, AND IN A ROCK 7 BY 6 FEET BY 6 FEET HIGH.

IT IS AT THE OUTER END OF THE RUSHES ALONG THE ST JOSEPH ISLAND SHORE, ABOUT 1,000 FEET S OF THE RAINSMERE HOTEL, AND OPPOSITE THE TWO HOUSES ON THE ROAD S OF THE HOTEL.  THE N FENCE OF THE SIDE ROAD LEADING TO THESE TWO HOUSES EXTENDED WOULD PASS 6 FEET N OF THE STATION.  THE ROCK THE STATION IS ON IS THE NEAREST TO THIS SIDE ROAD OF ANY LARGE ROCK ON THE ISLAND.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD I B C BRONZE DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A FLAT ROCK 5 BY 6 FEET BY 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) ON MONK POINT ON THE NW CORNER OF COCKBURN ISLAND, AT THE ENTRACE TO FALSE DETOUR CHANNEL.  IT IS ON A HOGBACK RIDGE RUNNING PARALLEL TO THE SHORE AND 75 FEET FROM IT, AND 30 FEET INSIDE THE TREE LINE. IT IS ABOUT 250 FEET S OF THE EXTREME NW TIP OF THE POINT AND THE SAME DISTANCE FROM THE SW TIP OF THIS FLAT POINT.  AN 18-FOOT TOWER WAS BUILT OVER THE STATION.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE I B C DISK IN USUAL CONCRETE CYLINDER SET WITH TOP 8 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND IN A LARGE CAIRN OF PURE WHITE ROCKS.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS THE USUAL COPPER WIRE IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER SET WITH TOP 12 INCHES UNDER THE SURFACE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

N-2. CONCRETE MONUMENT ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE NIAGARA PARKWAY, 4.2 KM (2.6 MI) NORTHWEST OF THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE, 1.9 KM (1.2 MI) NORTHWEST OF FRENCHMAN'S CREEK. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1925 ON NAMAKAN LAKE, ON EXTREME SOUTHERN END OF BLACKSTONE ISLAND WHICH IS CONNECTED WITH MAINLAND AT LOW WATER.  MARKED BY STANDARD STATION DISK IN ROCK.  REFERENCE MONUMENT 353 (IBC).  MARKED BY STANDARD 8-INCH MANGANESE-BRONZE POST OF INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION, IS 14.49 METERS (47.5 FEET) FROM STATION N 29 DEG 44 MIN E.  IN 1925, THE WATER LEVEL OF NAMAKAN LAKE WAS HIGH, STATION WAS PROBABLY UNDER SURFACE OF WATER AND WAS NOT FOUND.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE SOUTHERNMOST POINT OF NAVY ISLAND ON CANADIAN TERRITORY NEAR THE NORTHERNMOST POINT OF JUNCTION OF THE CHIPPEWA AND TONAWANDA CHANNELS OF THE NIAGARA RIVER.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM BIG SIXMILE CREEK MARINA IN GRAND ISLAND, NEW YORK LAUNCH A SKIFF AND PROCEED NORTHWESTWARD OUT OF THE CREEK TO THE CHIPPEWA CHANNEL OF THE NIAGARA RIVER. THENCE PROCEED NORTHWARD TO THE FIRST SMALL CLEAR MINI BLUFF WEST OF THE SOUTHERNMOST TIP OF NAVY ISLAND.  LAND THE SKIFF AND WALK UP THE MINI BLUFF TO THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A PLAIN BRASS DISK STAMPED---NAVY 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 25 CM IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 9.40 METERS (30.8 FT) WEST-NORTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF A 50 CM (20 INCH) DIAMETER OAK TREE, 6.70 METERS (22.0 FT) SOUTH-SOUTHWEST FROM THE CENTER OF A 20 CM (8 INCH) DIAMETER APPLE TREE, 2.35 METERS (7.7 FT) EAST-SOUTHEAST FROM THE CENTER OF A 61 CM (24 INCH) DIAMETER OAK TREE,  AND 2.0 METERS (6.6 FT) NORTH OF THE EDGE OF THE STEEP BANK OF THE MINI BLUFF.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.857 METERS.  DESCRIBED BY C. MIDDLETON.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF NAVY ISLAND AND ABOUT 1/4 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE SOUTH TIP OF THE ISLAND.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE THOMAS E DEWEY THRUWAY TOLL HOUSE ON THE NORTH END OF GRAND ISLAND, GO SOUTH ON INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 190 FOR 0.4 MILE TO THE FIRST EXIT RAMP, N20A.  BEAR RIGHT ONTO THE EXIT RAMP AND GO WEST ON THE WEST RIVER PARKWAY FOR 0.35 MILE TO A PUMPING STATION ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM THE REAR OF THE PUMPING STATION, TAKE A BOAT ON A MAGNETIC BEARING OF S63 DEGREES W FOR ABOUT 1/2 MILE TO THE SOUTHEAST SIDE OF NAVY ISLAND AND THE STATION.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED NAVY 2 1973, IS A BRONZE DISK CRIMPED TO A 9/16 - INCH IN DIAMETER, COPPER - COATED, STEEL ROD THAT IS DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND AND PROJECT 6 INCHES.  IT IS 35 FEET NORTHEAST OF A CLUSTER OF THE THREE BLACK LOCUST TREES, 2.5 FEET NORTH OF A 4 - INCH IN DIAMETER BLACK LOCUST TREE WITH A SMALL BLAZE AND AT THE EDGE OF THE RIVER BANK.  REFERENCE MARKS WERE NOT ESTABLISHED AT THIS STATION.  THIS STATION IS ON PROPERTY ADMINISTERED BY THE NIAGARA PARKS COMMISSION.  PERMISSION MUST BE OBTAINED FROM THEM BEFORE USING THIS STATION.
markers.setting: METAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

THE STATION IS 6 FEET FROM THE END OF THE LEDGE NEAREST SHORE AND ABOUT THE CENTER OF THE LEDGE IN THE UP AND DOWN STREAM DIRECTION.  STATION MRK IS A 3/4-INCH DRILL HOLE 3/4 INCH DEEP IN THE SOLID LEDGE ROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1958)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1958 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED IN ONTARIO CANADA NEAR THE WEST SHORELINE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, 0.40 MILES SOUTH OF MILLER ROAD, 0.15 MILES NORTH OF MARSHAL ROAD, 0.22 MILES SOUTH OF THE NELSON MOTEL ALONG THE PARK ROAD WHICH PARALLELS THE NIAGARA RIVER.  THE STATION IS A STANDARD BLANK DISK STAMPED---A 1980---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 20 CM IN DIAMETER FLUSH WITH GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 33.64 METERS (110.4 FT) EAST FROM A POWER POLE NUMBER CNP 535 11.47 METERS (37.63 FT) EAST FROM THE CENTERLINE OF ASPHALT ROAD 6.82 METERS (22.38 FT) NORTH FROM A 1 INCH WILLOW, 4.27 METERS (14.00 FT) SOUTH FROM A 1 INCH WILLOW 16.18 METERS (53.08 FT) NORTH FROM A PK NAIL AND WASHER IN A 6 INCH DIAMETER ASH TREE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.65 METERS.  DESCRIBED BY B DECROIX                            STATION RECOVERY (2015)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2015 (RLM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE POLE HAS BEEN REMOVED.  THE 1-INCH WILLOW TREE SOUTH OF THE MARK IS NOW A 17-INCH (43 CM) WILLOW, THE 1-INCH WILLOW TREE NORTH OF THE MARK IS NOW A 14-INCH (36 CM) WILLOW AND THE 6-INCH ASH TREE IS NOW A 14-INCH (36 CM) ASH.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1980 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED NEAR THE NORTH SIDE OF FORT ERIE, ONTARIO CANADA.  THE STATION IS 11.25 METERS OFF THE CENTERLINE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER PARKWAY AT THE MOUTH OF THE BLACK CREEK ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF THE CREEK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE PEACE BRIDGE CONNECTING THE U S WITH CANADA FOLLOW THE SIGNS TO THE NIAGARA RIVER PARKWAY AND FOLLOW THE PARKWAY FOR APPROXIMATELY 13.7 KM TO THE AREA OF THE BLACK CREEK AND THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION IS A BLANK DISK STAMPED---B 1980---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 15 CM IN DIAMETER RECESSED 6 CM BELOW THE GROUND.  IT IS LOCATED 15.21 METERS (49.90 FT) NORTHEAST FROM A WOOD POST SUPPORTING A STEEL GUARD RAIL, THE WESTERLY POST, 11.25 METERS (36.91 FT) NORTH FROM THE CENTERLINE OF THE ROAD, 5.53 METERS (18.14 FT) NORTH-NORTHEAST FROM A 17 INCH ASH, 3.02 METERS (9.90 FT) SOUTHEAST FROM A 8 INCH ASH, 2.73 METERS (8.96 FT) NORTHWEST FROM A 6 INCH ASH.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN ABOVE THE MARK WAS 1.80 METERS.                             STATION RECOVERY (2015)  RECOVERY NOTE BY GEOCACHING 2015 (RLM) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 6-INCH AND 17-INCH ASH TREES HAVE BEEN REMOVED AND THE 8-INCH ASH TREE IS NOW A 14-INCH (36 CM) ASH TREE.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1981 (RHH) THE STATION,ONTARIO BELL RELAY TOWER, IS THE POLE ON TOP HOLDING OR SUPPORTING TWIN LIGHTS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE CANADIAN TOWN OF SAULT STE MARIE, ONTARIO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CUSTOMS OFFICE AT THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE,WHICH CONNECTS ONTARIO TO MICHIGAN AT THE SOO, GO NORTH ON HURON STREET TO ITS JUNCTION WITH CATHCART STREET. TURN RIGHT ON CATHCART STREET AND GO EAST FOR 0.6 KILOMETER(0.4 MILE) TO ITS TERMINATION AT THE JUNCTION OF WELLINGTON STREET.  TURN RIGHT ON WELLINGTON STREET AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 1.4 KILOMETERS(0.9 MILE) TO A SIDE STREET ON THE LEFT CALLED FARQUIER AVENUE.  TURN LEFT ONTO FARQUIER AVENUE AND GO NORTH TO ITS END AND THE STATION DIRECTLY AHEAD.

DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1982 (RHH) THE STATION IS LOCATED ON THE WESTERN SHORE OF THE CHIPPAWA CHANNEL OF THE NIAGARA RIVER SOUTH OF THE ENTRANCE TO BAKER CREEK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BRIDGE OVER THE WELLAND RIVER IN TOWN OF CHIPPAWA, GO SOUTH AND EAST ON THE NIAGARA PARKWAY FOR 17.0 KM (10.6 MILES) TO SCHWEGLER ROAD ON THE RIGHT AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION IS A BLANK DISK STAMPED---D 1982---, SET INTO THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT 30 CM IN DIAMETER RECESSED 5 CM BELOW THE GROUND. IT IS LOCATED 14.26 METERS (56.8 FT) NORTH FROM THE CENTERLINE OF THE JUNCTION OF NIAGARA PARKWAY AND SCHWEGLER ROAD, 1.426 METERS (4.68 FT) SOUTH FROM THE TOP OF THE WOODEN STAIRWAY DOWN TO THE BOATHOUSE, AND ON LINE WITH CENTERLINE OF SCHWEGLER ROAD. ON THE WEST BANK OF THE NIAGARA RIVER AT ITS MOUTH AT LAKE ONTARIO, WITHIN THE CONFINES OF FT. MISSISSAUGA -- DIRECTLY ACROSS THE NIAGARA RIVER FROM FT. NIAGARA (N. Y.).  TO REACH THE STATION, PROCEED NORTH ON NIAGARA PARKWAY ROAD FROM THE LEWISTON BRIDGE APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES TO THE INTERSECTION OF FRONT AND SIMCOE STREETS AND THE NIAGARA GOLF COURSE.  PROCEED NORTH, ON FOOT, FOR ABOUT 350 FEET ACROSS THE GOLF COURSE TO FOOT PATH ATOP BLUFF EAST OF THE OLD FORT MISSISSAUGA, TOWARDS OLD FORT MISSISSAUGA LIGHT AND THE STATION.  STATION IS LOCATED 77.9 FEET SOUTHWEST OF FORT MISSISSAUGA ENTRANCE LIGHT, 107.8 FEET EAST OF SOUTHERLY CORNER POST OF FENCE SURROUNDING OLD FORT MISSISSAUGA, 151.5 FEET SOUTH SOUTHWEST OF TUNNEL RUNNING UNDER BLUFF.  STATION MARK IS A 1 INCH SQUARE IRON ROD WITH A CROSS CUT ON TOP.  ALSO 3 INCH ROUND IDENTIFICATION DISK WITH THE NUMBER 567 STAMPED ON IT IS SET AROUND SQUARE ROD (AGENCY UNKNOWN).

THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRASS SCREW SET 2 FEET UNDERGROUND IN THE TOP OF AN 8 - INCH CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS A DRILL HOLE IN THE BOTTOM STONE OF A CUT - STONE ORNAMENTAL FENCE NORTHEAST OF A SET OF CIRCULAR STONE STEPS.  NO 2 IS THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE BOTTOM STEP OF A SET OF FOUR STEPS LEADING UP TO A TERRACE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) THE STATION AND REFERENCE NO 1 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE NO 2 WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE STATION IS 14 FEET WEST OF THE WEST SIDE OF A CONCRETE WALL THAT IS 8 INCHES HIGH AND 6 INCHES WIDE THAT HOLDS AN IRON FENCE ON THE OVERLOOK JUST WEST OF THE POWER BUILDING, 5.3 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF CUT ROCK BANK, 4 FEET SOUTH OF A STEEL, WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED AND 1 FOOT UNDER THE GRAVEL FILL.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ABOUT 3-1/2 MILES WEST OF EMO, 637 METERS (2,090 FEET) WEST OF MILEPOST 112 OF CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY, 87 METERS (285 FEET) EAST OF ROAD CROSSING AT TOBAS, AND 1.456 METERS (4.77 FEET) SOUTH OF EXTENSION OF SOUTH RAIL FROM EAST.  SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE STANDARD STATION DISKS IN COCNRETE. REFERENCE MARK IS STANDARD REFERENCE DISK IN CONCRETE, 90.70 METERS (297.6 FEET) FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (LMC) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE REFERENCE MARK HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  AN AZIMUTH MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 AND 3 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  THE TOWER WAS BUILT OVER R.M. NO. 2 DUE TO THE STATION MARK BEING TOO CLOSE TO THE RAILROAD TRACK.  A TRAVERSE CONNECTION WAS MADE BETWEEN THE STATION MARK AND R.M. NO. 2.  DUE TO THE VARIOUS CHANGES A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3 MILES EAST OF BARWICK, 3 MILES WEST OF EMO, 1/2 MILE NORTH OF THE RAINY RIVER AND ON MANITOU RAPIDS INDIAN RESERVE.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF KINGS HIGHWAYS 11 AND 71 AND ONTARIO HIGHWAY 602 IN EMO, GO WEST ON HIGHWAY 11 AND 71 FOR 3.75 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT, JUST BEFORE REACHING THE POINT WHERE HIGHWAY 71 TURNS NORTH.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH ON A GRAVELED ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A FIELD ROAD LEFT JUST AFTER CROSSING A RAILROAD TRACK.  TURN LEFT AND GO EAST ON THE FIELD ROAD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION AS DESCRIBED.  STATION MARK, A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A SQUARE CONCRETE MONUMENT, STAMPED PAT 1923, IS SET 2 FEET BELOW THE GROUND SURFACE.  IT IS 64 FEET NORTHEAST OF TELEPHONE POLE NUMBER 7, 52 FEET SOUTH OF AN 8-INCH POPLAR TREE WITH A TRIANGLE BLAZED ON THE SOUTH SIDE AND 9.9 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK.  R.M. NO. 2, A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT, STAMPED PAT NO 2 1923 1967, PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 59 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK, 29 FEET SOUTHEAST OF TELEPHONE POLE NUMBER 7 AND 2.7 FEET WEST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  R.M. NO. 3, A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT, STAMPED PAT NO 3 1923 1967, PROJECTS 12 INCHES.  IT IS 56 FEET SOUTHWEST OF TELEPHONE POLE NUMBER 7, 46 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK AND 1.5 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  AZIMUTH MARK, A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT, STAMPED PAT 1923 1967, PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 61 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER OF A DIRT TRACK ROAD AND 2.7 FEET WEST OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THE RAILROAD CROSSING, GO SOUTH ON A DIRT TRACK ROAD FOR 0.25 MILE TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1969 (CWB) THIS STATION WAS PART OF A FIRST ORDER TRAVERSE RAN BY C.M. DURGIN (USC AND GS) IN 1923 AND ONE OF THE REFERENCE MARKS, CALLED R.M. NO. 2, WAS PART OF A SECOND ORDER TRIANGULATION SURVEY BY L.M. CHASE (USC AND GS) IN 1967.  THE STATION, AZIMUTH, AND BOTH REFERENCE MARKS, 2 AND 3, WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1923 REFERENCE MARK HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  THE 1967 DESCRIPTION BY G.M.B. UNDER CHIEF OF PARTY L.M. CHASE (USC AND GS) WAS FOUND TO BE GOOD.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--3 MILES EAST OF BARWICK, ONTARIO, CANADA.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ABOUT 200 METERS (656 FEET) WEST OF CROZIER RAILWAY STATION AND 2.22 METERS (7.3 FEET) SOUTH OF SOUTH RAIL AT HIGHEST POINT IN TRACK OF CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY.  SURFACE AND UNDERGROUND MARKS ARE STANDARD STATION DISKS IN CONCRETE. REFERENCE MARK IS STANDARD REFERENCE DISK IN CONCRETE, 23.9 METERS (78 FEET) FROM STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1966)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1966 (GCR) THE STATION WAS VISITED.  THE STATION MARK WAS FOUND OUT OF POSITION, AND ON ITS SIDE.  AFTER CONSIDERABLE DIGGING THE UNDERGROUND MARK WAS RECOVERED AND IS BELIEVED TO BE IN ITS ORIGINAL POSITION.  THE REFERENCE MARK WAS SEARCHED FOR BUT COULD NOT BE FOUND.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 7 MILES WEST OF FORT FRANCES, 6 MILES EAST OF DEVLIN, 0.35 MILE SOUTH OF THE SMALL STORE AND POST OFFICE AT CROZIER AND ON THE SOUTH RIGHT-OF-WAY OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE STORE AND POST OFFICE IN CROZIER ON THE KINGS HIGHWAY 11 AND 71, GO SOUTH ON A TRACK SECTION LINE ROAD FOR 0.35 MILES TO THE RAILROAD.  FROM THIS POINT THE STATION IS 972 FEET WEST OF THE CENTERLINE OF THE CROSSING (MEASURED). TO REACH THE MONUMENT FROM THE JUNCTION OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 190 AND WEST RIVER PARKWAY ON GRAND ISLAND, THIS IS THE MOST NORTHERLY INTERCHANGE ON GRAND ISLAND, GO WEST ON WEST RIVER PARKWAY FOR 0.35 MILE TO A PUMPING STATION ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL. THE MONUMENT IS A CONE - SHAPED, CONCRETE STRUCTURE WITH A HEMISPHERICAL TOP.  THE MONUMENT IS 2 FEET IN DIAMETER AT THE BASE, 1-1/2 FEET IN DIAMETER AT THE TOP, WITH A RADIUS FOR THE HEMISPHERICAL CROWN OF 9 INCHES, AND IT PROJECTS 2-1/2 FEET. THIS MONUMENT IS ON PROPERTY ADMINISTERED BY THE NIAGARA PARKS COMMISSION.  OBTAIN THEIR PERMISSION BEFORE VISITING THE MONUMENT.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1904 NEAR THE CENTER OF COCKBURN ISLAND AND NEAR THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE HILL IN WHAT IS KNOWN AS THE SCOTCH BLOCK.  IT IS IN THE ROAD RIGHT - OF - WAY (ON THE MAIN ROAD FROM THE COASTAL VILLAGE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THENCE S TO THE SCHOOLHOUSE) AND IS 10.5 FEET W OF THE E FENCE AT A POINT 200 FEET S OF THE BEND IN THE ROAD AT THE TOP OF THE LAST STEEP GRADE IN THE ROAD.  IT IS 5 FEET OUTSIDE THE E DITCH OF THE ROAD AND 16 FEET FROM THE CENTER OF THE ROAD, IN A SMALL DEPRESSION 3 FEET ACROSS AND 6 INCHES DEEP.  THE HIGHEST POINT ON THE HILL IS ABOUT 500 FEET S OF THE STATION.  THE CONCRETE REFERENCE MARK IS GONE.  THE STONE HEAPS ARE STILL THERE BUT THERE ARE SO MANY OTHERS THAT THEY CANNOT BE IDENTIFIED TILL THE STATION IS FOUND.  ONE OF THE BARNS IS GONE AND THE OTHER HIDDEN BY A GROWTH OF TIMBER.  STATION MARK--A LARGE SPIKE IN THE CENTER OF THREE OTHERS SET IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT WHOSE TOP IS FLUSH WITH THE GROUND IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DEPRESSION MENTIONED ABOVE.  THE SPIKES ARE BENT OVER FLAT.  THE CONCRETE IS MARKED---U.S.L.S. 1903---.                            STATION RECOVERY (1944)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARKS--DRILL HOLES WERE MADE IN FOUR SOLID ROCKS THIS YEAR AND ARE DESCRIBED AS FOLLOWS--  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS IN A ROCK 3 BY 2 FEET BY 1 FOOT HIGH IN THE ROAD RIGHT - OF - WAY, NW FROM THE STATION AND 8 FEET FROM THE E FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS A ROCK 1-1/2 FEET BY 1-1/2 FEET BY 1 FOOT HIGH, NE OF THE STATION, IN AN OPEN FIELD, 40 FEET INSIDE THE FENCE LINE.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS IN A ROCK 2 BY 1-1/2 FEET BY 3 INCHES HIGH, SE OF THE STATION, IN THE ROADWAY, 2 FEET FROM THE E FENCE.  REFERENCE MARK 4 IS IN A ROCK 2-1/2 BY 2-1/2 FEET BY 1 FOOT HIGH ACROSS THE ROAD, IN THE BUSHES AT THE TOP OF THE STEEP BANK.

DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1929 (CMT) LOCATED IN AN OPEN FIELD NEAR A GRAVEL PIT AT THE SW INTERSECTION OF TWO ROADS, ABOUT 1/2 MILE SW OF THE VILLAGE OF RIDGEWAY AND 1/2 MILE N OF CRYSTAL BEACH IN TOWNSHIP OF BERTIE COUNTY OF WELLAND PROVINCE OF ONTARIO. REFERENCE MARK NO.3 IS ON BANK IN ROW OF BUSHES ABOUT 6 METERS S OF CENTER LINE OF ROAD.  HEIGHT OF SIGNAL ABOVE STATION MARK - 26 METERS. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) ON THE TOP OF THE HILL NEAR THE CENTER OF COCKBURN ISLAND, IN THE SETTLEMENT KNOWN AS THE SCOTCH BLOCK.  TO REACH THE STATION, FOLLOW THE ROAD FROM COCKBURN ISLAND VILLAGE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL.  HERE IS A LEFT BEND IN THE ROAD.  THE STATION IS IN AN OPEN FIELD ON THE RIGHT OR W SIDE OF THE ROAD AT THE BEND.  IT IS 75 FEET FROM THE W END OF THE HIGH RIDGE RUNNING W FROM THE ROAD AND ABOUT 500 FEET FROM THE ROAD.  THE RIDGE BRANCHES NEAR THE STATION, ONE BRANCH RUNNING N ABOUT 100 FEET, AND ONE 300 FEET SW TO A HOGBACK RUNNING NW AND SE.  THE STATION IS 25 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE RIDGE, ON THE SE SIDE.  IT IS 35 FEET N OF THE LINE OF TWO STONE PILES, IN THE VALLEY W OF THE STATION, EXTENDED.  STATION MARK IS A STANDARD BRONZE I B C DISK IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER SET WITH THE TOP 4 INCHES ABOVE THE GROUND IN A CAIRN.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS THE USUAL COPPER WIRE IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER SET WITH ITS TOP 20 INCHES UNDERGROUND.  REFERENCE MARKS ARE DRILL HOLES IN DEEPLY EMBEDDED ROCKS ON THE RIDGE.  REFERENCE MARK 1 IS ENE, IN A ROCK 3 FEET BY 1 FOOT BY 2 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.  REFERENCE MARK 2 IS SE, IN A ROCK 2 BY 3 FEET BY 3 INCHES ABOVE GROUND, AT EDGE OF HILL.  REFERENCE MARK 3 IS SW, IN A ROCK 3 BY 2-1/2 FEET BY 6 INCHES ABOVE GROUND.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 2 MILES NORTH OF THE VILLAGE OF CHIPPAWA.  THE STATION IS 0.3 MILE NORTH OF A SCHOOLHOUSE AT A ROAD INTERSECTION AND OPPOSITE THE SOUTH END OF A ROW OF SPRUCE TREES GROWING ALONG THE WEST SIDE OF QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY.  TWO OF THESE TREES, DIRECTLY ACROSS THE PARKWAY FROM THE STATION, ARE BLAZED.  THE STATION IS 18 FEET EAST OF THE CENTER OF THE PARKWAY, 3 FEET FROM THE RIVER BANK, 25 FEET FROM THE WATERS EDGE, AND 163 FEET NORTH OF AN ARROW CUT ON A CONCRETE CULVERT.  IT IS ABOUT 4 FEET EAST OF THE THIRD POST OF THE EAST GUARD RAIL OF THE PARKWAY, COUNTING NORTH FROM THE SOUTHERN END OF THE GUARD RAIL.  STATION MARK, A BRASS BOLT 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER SET 6 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE. THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS A USLS STANDARD BRONZE - DISK REFERENCE MARK SET, WITH THE ARROW POINTING TOWARD THE STATION, 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  IT IS ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE PARKWAY AT THE SOUTH END OF THE GUARD RAIL AND BEARS S - 23 DEGREES - W FROM THE STATION, DISTANT 22.30 FEET.  NO 2 IS A SIMILAR MARK SITUATED IN THE ROW OF SPRUCE TREES ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  IT BEARS N - 60 DEGREES - W FROM THE STATION, DISTANT 41.72 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 2 MILES SOUTHEAST OF CHIPPAWA, ONTARIO AND ON NIAGARA PARKS COMMISSION PROPERTY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BRIDGE OVER USSHERS CREEK ON THE QUEEN VICTORIA PARK BOULEVARD, THIS IS ABOUT 2 MILES, BY ROAD, SOUTH OF CHIPPAWA, GO SOUTHEAST AND SOUTH ON THE BOULEVARD FOR 1.0 MILE TO THE SOUTH END OF A GUARDRAIL AND THE STATION ON THE LEFT.  THE STATION MARK IS A 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER BRASS BOLT SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THAT IS 6 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 163 FEET NORTH OF A CHISELED ARROW IN A CONCRETE CULVERT THAT IS BELOW THE RIVER BANK, 26 FEET NORTH - NORTHEAST OF A BLAZED ELM TREE THAT IS AT THE SOUTH END OF THE GUARD RAIL, 20 FEET EAST - SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE BOULEVARD, 6 FEET WEST OF THE RIVER BANK, AND 4.2 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE THIRD POST FROM THE SOUTH END OF THE GUARD RAIL.  REFERENCE MARK 1, STAMPED NO 1 SPRUCE 1909, IS A BRONZE, US LAKE SURVEY REFERENCE MARK DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THAT IS 5 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND FLUSH WITH THE GROUND.  IT IS 140 FEET NORTH OF THE CHISELED ARROW IN THE CONCRETE CULVERT, 19 FEET EAST - SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE BOULEVARD, 4 FEET NORTH - NORTHWEST OF THE BLAZED ELM TREE, AND 2.8 FEET EAST - SOUTHEAST OF THE MOST SOUTHERLY POST OF THE GUARD RAIL.
markers.setting: SET IN PREFABRICATED CONCRETE POST IMBEDDED IN GROUND

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ABOUT 6-1/3 MILES EAST OF EMO, 546 METERS (1,791 FEET) EAST OF MILEPOST 104 OF CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY, ON HILL NEAR BISHOPS FARM, AND 9.12 METERS (29.9 FEET) NORTH OF SOUTH RAIL. STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (LMC) THE STATION MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 1 WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW AZIMUTH MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  THE TOWER HAD TO BE BUILT OVER R.M. NO. 2 BECAUSE THE STATION MARK WAS TOO CLOSE TO A RAILROAD TRACK.  DUE TO THE CHANGES A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 6 MILES EAST OF EMO, 2 MILES WEST OF DEVLIN, 1 MILE SOUTH OF KINGS HIGHWAYS 11 AND 71 AND ON THE NORTH RIGHT-OF-WAY OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILROAD.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE JUNCTION OF KINGS HIGHWAYS 11 AND 71 AND ONTARIO HIGHWAY 613 IN DEVLIN, GO WEST ON HIGHWAYS 11 AND 71 FOR 3.85 MILES TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  TURN LEFT AND GO SOUTH, EAST AND SOUTH ON A TRACK ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD LEFT.  CONTINUE SOUTH ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.45 MILE TO WHERE THE MAIN TRACK ROAD TURNS LEFT AND A DIM TRACK ROAD CONTINUES AHEAD.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM THIS POINT, CONTINUE AHEAD ON THE DIM TRACK ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO A RAILROAD TRACK AND THE MARK ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE TRACK.) TURN LEFT AND GO EAST AND SOUTH ON THE TRACK ROAD FOR 0.7 MILE TO AN ABANDONED SHACK, A 20 FOOT TRIPOD AND A DIM FIELD ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO WEST AND SOUTH ON THE DIM FIELD ROAD FOR 0.15 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE RAILROAD TRACK. NO. 1, STAMPED STONE NO 1 1923 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN AN OUTCROPPING OF BEDROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 FOOT. IT IS 23.9 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK, 23.8 FEET NORTH OF A FENCE LINE AND 17 FEET NORTHWEST OF POWER POLE NUMBER 4220.  R.M. NO. 2, STAMPED STONE NO 2 1923 1967 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 5 INCHES. IT IS 40.6 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK, 7.5 FEET SOUTH OF A FENCE LINE AND 2.4 FEET SOUTH OF A METAL WITNESS POST.  AZIMUTH MARK, STAMPED STONE 1923 1967 IS A STANDARD DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A ROUND CONCRETE MONUMENT WHICH PROJECTS 4 INCHES. IT IS 36.6 FEET SOUTH OF THE SOUTH RAIL OF THE RAILROAD TRACK, 1.8 FEET NORTHWEST OF A METAL WITNESS POST AND 1.6 FEET EAST OF A POWER POLE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1 METERS.

THREE STONE REFERENCE POSTS ARE SET AS FOLLOWS--ONE, MARKED U.S. ON TOP, ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE TOWN LINE ROAD BETWEEN THE TOWNS OF WAMFLEET AND HUMBERSTONE, PROJECTING 8 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE, BEARING NORTH 0 DEG 19 MIN EAST, DISTANT 252.31 METERS.  ONE, MARKED WITH A CROSS ON TOP AND L.S. ON SOUTH FACE NEAR TOP, PROJECTING 9 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE, AT THE FOOT OF THE HILL, NEAR THE CORNER OF A FIELD, BEARING NORTH 64 DEG 04 MIN EAST, DISTANT 82.21 METERS. AND ONE MARKED WITH A CROSS ON TOP, PROJECTING 6 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE ON TOP OF THE HILL, BEARING SOUTH 43 DEG 11 MIN EAST, DISTANT 16.9 METERS FROM THE GEODETIC POINT.  THE PORT COLBORNE LIGHTHOUSE BEARS NORTH 84 DEG 49 MIN EAST.  THE HEIGHT OF GROUND AT THE STATION ABOVE MEAN LEVEL OF LAKE ERIE IS 141.2 FEET.                            STATION RECOVERY (1928)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1928 (CAS) SUGAR LOAF HILL RISES PROMINENTLY JUST SOUTH OF A T-ROAD INTERSECTION, FORMED BY A MACADAM ROAD RUNNING EAST AND WEST AND A CONCRETE ROAD RUNNING INTO IT FROM THE NORTH.  THE MARKS WERE FOUND APPARENTLY AS ESTABLISHED.  REFERENCE MARK NO.1 WAS FOUND ALONG THE EAST FENCE ALONG THE CONCRETE ROAD TO THE NORTH OF THE STATION.  THE REFERENCE MARK ON THE TOP OF THE HILL WAS NOT FOUND BUT ONLY A FEW MINUTES WERE SPENT IN SEARCHING FOR IT.  THE ONE AT THE FOOT OF THE HILL HAS BEEN REMOVED.  A STONE POST NOT MENTIONED IN THE ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION WAS FOUND ON TOP OF THE HILL ABOUT 2 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT WAS THE SAME SIZE AND OF THE SAME STONE AS THE MARK USED BY THE U.S. LAKE SURVEY.  THE HILL IS COMPOSED OF A VERY FINE SANDY SOIL SO IT IS EASY TO FIND AN UNDERGROUND MARK WITH A BAR.  THE VERY TOP OF THE HILL IS BARE BUT TREES ON THE SOUTHERN SLOPE RISE ABOUT 25 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL.  ALL NECESSARY LINES COULD READILY BE CLEARED, BUT MRS. EDWARD WEGRICH, THE OWNER OF THE LAND, IS OPPOSED TO HAVING ANY TREES CUT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1929)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1929 (CMT) THE ORIGINAL U.S. LAKE SURVEY MARK, 2 FEET BELOW THE SURFACE OF GROUND, WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT CONSISTED OF THE USUAL LAKE SURVEY STONE POST, ABOUT 7 INCHES SQUARE ON TOP, WITH SMALL HOLE IN TOP OF SAME.  THIS STONE POST WAS USED AS OUR SUBSURFACE MARK, AND A CONCRETE POST WITH A STANDARD CANADIAN TRIANGULATION MARK (FURNISHED BY THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA AND SET IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE POST) WAS CENTERED OVER THE HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE STONE POST DESCRIBED ABOVE.  THE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARK ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE TOWN LINE ROAD, NORTH OF SUGAR LOAF HILL, WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED, AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE OLD REFERENCE MARK AT THE FOOT OF THE HILL COULD NOT BE RECOVERED.  IT HAD EVIDENTLY BEEN DESTROYED, AS A THOROUGH SEARCH WAS MADE FOR SAME.  THE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARK ON TOP OF SUGAR LOAF HILL WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN FAIR CONDITION, THE TOP OF THE MARK BEING SOMEWHAT JAGGED.  THE OLD AND NEW DISTANCES TO THE MARK CHECKED GOOD AND SO DID THE ANGLE BETWEEN THESE ORIGINAL REFERENCE MARKS.  A THIRD REFERENCE MARK WAS RECENTLY ESTABLISHED, AND DISTANCES AND DIRECTIONS TO IT WERE MEASURED.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

STATION RECOVERY (1967)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1967 (LMC) STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE MARK HAS BEEN DISTURBED AND IS TILTED TO THE WEST.  AN AZIMUTH MARK AND REFERENCE MARK 2 WERE ESTABLISHED AT THIS TIME.  DUE TO VARIOUS REASONS A COMPLETE NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  STATION IS LOCATED 3/4 MILE NORTHEAST OF BAUDETTE, MINNESOTA, 1 MILE WEST OF RAINY RIVER, ON FIRST CURVE OF CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY, 0.15 MILE NORTHEAST OF INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE AND 0.1 MILE NORTH OF INTERSECTION OF HIGHWAY 11 AND 600.  STATION IS ON PROPERTY OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILWAY AND THE REFERENCE MARK IS ON PROPERTY OF MR. ALEC WARNUK.  TO REACH STATION FROM JUNCTION OF STATE ROUTES 11 AND 72 IN THE BUSINESS SECTION OF BAUDETTE, MINNESOTA, GO NORTH ON STATE ROUTE 72 TOWARD THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE FOR 0.45 MILE TO U.S. CUSTOMS AND TOLL GATE, CONTINUE NORTHEAST CROSSING THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE FOR 0.4 MILE TO CANDIAN CUSTOMS.  CONTINUE NORTHEAST ON HIGHWAY 11 FOR 0.1 MILE TO JUNCTION OF ONTARIO HIGHWAYS 11 AND 600.  (TO REACH THE AZIMUTH MARK FROM HERE, CONTINUE AHEAD ON HIGHWAY 11 AND GO EAST FOR 0.2 MILE TO MARK ON RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.) TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH ON HIGHWAY 600 FOR 0.1 MILE TO STATION ON RIGHT AS DESCRIBED.  ALL MARKS ARE STANDARD DISKS SET IN CONCRETE POSTS.  STATION MARK, STAMPED TOAD 1923, IS SET FLUSH.  IT IS 118 FEET EAST OF CENTER OF HIGHWAY 600, 94 FEET NORTHEAST OF GUY LINE BRACE POLE AND 2 FEET NORTHWEST OF WITNESS POST.  REFERENCE MARK, STAMPED TOAD 1923, IS SET FLUSH.  IT IS 61 FEET NORTH OF CENTER OF DRIVEWAY TO HOUSE, 26 FEET WEST OF CENTER OF HIGHWAY 600, 5.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF UTILITY POLE AND 4 FEET SOUTHWEST OF FENCE CORNER.  R.M. 2, STAMPED TOAD 1923 NO 2 1967, PROJECTS 8 INCHES.  IT IS 69.5 FEET EAST OF CENTER OF HIGHWAY 600 AND 2.5 FEET SOUTHWEST OF WITNESS POST.  AZIMUTH MARK, STAMPED TOAD 1923 1967, IS SET FLUSH.  IT IS 44 FEET EAST OF CENTER OF ROAD, 33.5 FEET SOUTH OF CENTER OF HIGHWAY 11 AND 14.3 FEET SOUTHEAST OF EAST END OF METAL CULVERT.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 126 FEET.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1 MILE WEST OF RAINY RIVER                            STATION RECOVERY (1969)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1969 (CWB) STATION MARK AND ALL REFERENCE MARKS WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  THE 1967 DESCRIPTION BY L.M. CHASE (USC AND GS) WAS FOUND TO BE GOOD.  AIRLINE DISTANCE AND DIRECTION FROM NEAREST TOWN--1 MILE WEST OF RAINY RIVER, ONTARIO, CANADA

DESCRIBED BY US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS 1988 (RAB) THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 3.9 KM (2.4 MI) EAST OF SAULT STE MARIE, ONTARIO ON WHAT IS KNOWN AS TOPSAIL ISLAND IN PARCEL 21 IN THE REGISTER FOR ALGOMA. OWNERSHIP---CITY OF SAULT STE MARIE  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE POST OFFICE IN SAULT STE MARIE MI, GO EAST FOR 0.2 KM (0.15 MI) ON RIDGE STREET TO THE INTERSECTION OF RIDGE STREET AND ASHMUN STREET, TURN LEFT AND GO NORTH FOR 0.2 KM (0.1 MI) ON ASHMUN STREET TO PORTAGE AVENUE, TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 3.0 KM (1.85 MI) ON PORTAGE AVENUE TO AUNE OSBORNE BOAT LAUNCH. TRAVEL BY BOAT ACROSS THE RIVER TO TOPSAIL ISLAND AND THE STATION.  THE STATION IS A POURED IN PLACE CONCRETE MONUMENT THAT IS STAMPED---LR2+008---, LOCATED UNDER A LARGE METAL TRIPOD WHICH IS 21.3 M (70 FT) INLAND FROM THE SHORELINE.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT SHOWN WAS 1.8 METERS ABOVE THE MARK.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL OCEAN SERVICE 1981 (RHH) THE STATION, TOPSAIL ISLAND OLD TOWER, IS THE CENTER OF THE PEAKED VENT ATOP THE ROOF OF THE LIGHTHOUSE SHAPED TOWER ON TOPSAIL ISLAND, CANADA.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ON A PROMINENT POINT OF TOPSAIL ISLAND WHICH PROJECTS INTO THE ST MARYS RIVER, WITHIN BELLVIEW PARK.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CUSTOMS OFFICE ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE IN SAULT STE MARIE, ONTARIO GO SOUTH ON HURON STREET TO ITS JUNCTION WITH QUEENS STREET. TURN LEFT ON QUEENS STREET AND GO SOUTHEAST FOR 10.5 KILOMETERS (6.5 MILES) TO THE ENTRANCE TO BELLVIEW PARK ON THE RIGHT. TURN RIGHT INTO THE PARK AND DRIVE TO THE SOUTHERN MOST END OF THE PARK AND THE AREA OF THE STATION ON THE PROMINENT POINT OF LAND JUTTING INTO THE ST MARYS RIVER.

DESCRIBED BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1923 (CMD) ON VERY HIGH, ROCK, TIMBERED POINT ABOUT 2/3 MILE NORTH OF NORTH SHORE OF NAMAKAN LAKE, ABOUT ONE MILE FROM EAST END OF LAKE, AND ABOUT 2 MILES AIRLINE NEARLY DUE NORTH OF NAMAKAN NARROWS.  THERE ARE SEVERAL ISLANDS IN LAKE AT THIS POINT AND SMALL BAY TO NORTH.  STATION BEARS A LITTLE WEST OF NORTH FROM HEAD OF BAY.  MARKED BY STANDARD STATION DISK IN ROCK.  REFERENCE MARK IS A STANDARD REFERENCE DISK IN ROCK, 9.09 METERS (29.8 FEET) FROM STATION.  A U.S. AND CANADIAN BOUNDARY SURVEY BRONZE DISK SET IN CEMENT AND ROCK IS 52.26 METERS FROM STATION N 31 DEG 46 MIN E. AN IRON REFERENCE BOLT IS 9.12 METERS EAST, AND A SECOND BOLT IS 5.60 METERS SOUTH OF THE U.S. AND C.B. SURVEY STATION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1948)  RECOVERY NOTE BY COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY 1948 (CAS) STATION IS TWO AND THREE-QUARTER MILES NORTH OF THE NORTH END OF NAMAKAN NARROWS, TWO AND ONE-QUARTER MILES NORTHEAST OF NEIL BERGERS CAMP AT THE EAST END OF NAMAKAN LAKE, AND TWO-THIRDS OF A MILE NORTH OF NAMAKAN LAKE.  LOCATED ON CROWN LANDS ON TOP OF A HIGH ROCKY HILL WHICH IS COVERED WITH MANY DEAD NORWAY PINE TREES AND IS EASILY RECOGNIZED AT A CONSIDERABLE DISTANCE BY THESE DEAD SNAGS.  STATION HAS BEEN RE-MARKED WITH A STANDARD USC AND GS BRONZE DISC SET IN BEDROCK AND STAMPED TOWER 1923.  TO REACH STATION FROM CRANE LAKE POST OFFICE, GO BY MOTOR BOAT NORTH THROUGH CRANE LAKE AND NARROWS TO SAND POINT LAKE. CONTINUE NORTH THROUGH SAND POINT LAKE TO NORTH END OF NAMAKAN NARROWS.  GO DUE NORTH ACROSS NAMAKAN LAKE FOR 2 MILES TO A SAND BEACH COVE AT AN OLD LOGGING CAMP (NOTHING OF WHICH REMAINS) AND A TRIANGULAR BLAZED ASPEN TREE ON THE SHORE LINE.  (THIS COVE IS JUST EAST OF MUD BAY WHICH IS NORTH OF A GROUP OF TINY ISLANDS.) FROM HERE GO NORTHWEST THROUGH OLD CAMP CLEARING FOR 100 PACES TO A TRIANGULAR BLAZED ASPEN TREE AT THE EDGE OF WOODS.  AT THIS POINT TAKE BLAZED LOGGING ROAD (DIM) NORTH FOR 100 PACES TO A FORK AND A TRIANGULAR BLAZED ASPEN TREE.  TAKE LEFT FORK OF A DIM, BLAZED LOGGING ROAD AND FOLLOW IT IN A GENERALLY NORTHWEST DIRECTION FOR THREE-QUARTERS OF A MILE TO A TRIANGULAR BLAZED ASPEN TREE ON THE RIGHT.  FROM HERE TAKE BLAZED TRAIL TO LEFT FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE-EIGHTH OF A MILE TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 1 IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISC SET IN BEDROCK AND STAMPED TOWER 1923.  IT IS NORTH OF THE STATION.  REFERENCE MARK NO. 2 IS A STANDARD BRONZE DISC SET IN BEDROCK AND STAMPED TOWER 1923 NO 2 IBC.  IT IS SOUTHEAST OF THE STATION.  THERE IS NO AZIMUTH MARK FOR THIS STATION.  WALTER SCOTT, A GUIDE WHO LIVES ON CRANE LAKE, NEAR THE POST OFFICE, HAS A GOOD BOAT AND HAVING BEEN TO THE STATION ON SEVERAL OCCASIONS KNOWS ITS LOCATION, AND WHERE THE LINES HAVE BEEN CLEARED TO OTHER STATIONS.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1914 (JH) ON THE NORTH BANK OF RAINY RIVER, ABOUT SEVEN - EIGHTHS MILE WEST OF PINEWOOD, ONTARIO.  THE STATION IS ON TOP OF THE BANK ABOUT 5 METERS ABOVE AND 8 METERS BACK FROM THE RIVERS EDGE.  THERE IS A SWALE ABOUT 8 METERS NORTHEAST OF THE STATION AND AN OLD STUMP ABOUT 12 METERS WEST.  STATION MARK--A CROSS CUT IN A STONE.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BALL OF WIRE.
markers.stability: MAY HOLD, BUT OF TYPE COMMONLY SUBJECT TOSURFACE MOTION

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1916 ON BURNED-OVER HILL, ABOUT 2 MILES FROM NORTHEAST CORNER OF LOUISA LAKE.  MARKED BY COPPER BOLT STAMPED G. S. C. 1916.
markers.stability: MARK OF QUESTIONABLE OR UNKNOWN STABILITY

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1878 ON THE PROMINENT POINT 3/4 MILE S OF PUMPKIN POINT, ON THE CANADIAN SHORE OF LOWER LAKE GEORGE.  IT WAS RECOVERED FROM A SUBSIDIARY AND IS LOCATED 30 FEET FROM THE WATER AND 5 FEET ABOVE IT.  IT IS ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE TWO PRONGE ON THIS PROMINENT POINT.  STATION MARK--WHEN THE LONG CEDAR POST WAS REMOVED THE BOTTOM OF THE HOLE FILLED WITH WATER AND THE OLD SUBSURFACE MARK COULD NOT BE RECOVERED.  A FLAT ROCK WITH A DRILL HOLE IN IT WAS BURIED 2 FEET UNDERGROUND WHERE THE CENTER OF THE CEDAR POST WAS.  A STANDARD I B C BRONZE DISK IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE WAS SET OVER THE STATION WITH THE TOP FLUSH WITH SURFACE AND A CAIRN BUILT OVER IT.
markers.setting: SET IN TOP OF CONCRETE MONUMENT

A CEDAR POST SOLID UNDERGROUND BUT STARTING TO DECAY ABOVE GROUND WAS OVER THE STATION IN 1958.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY US LAKE SURVEY 1878 ON STRIBLINGS POINT AT THE NW CORNER OF ST JOSEPH ISLAND, OPPOSITE THE SMALL ISLANDS OFF THE POINT TO THE W. THERE IS SOME LOW BRUSH AROUND THE STATION WITH CLEARED LAND TOWARD THE RANGE AND ALSO INLAND TOWARD THE REAR RANGE.  STATION MARK IS A DRILL HOLE IN A SMOOTH ROCK UNDERGROUND.  A GOOD CEDAR POST WITH A NAIL IN ITS TOP IS OVER THE STATION.  A 10-FOOT TRIPOD PAINTED WHITE WITH AN OBSERVING STAND AROUND IT IS OVER THE STATION. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ON THE TOP OF THE HIGH CLIFF OVERLOOKING THE RIVER, ON A PROMINENT POINT OF LAND ABOUT ONE - FOURTH MILE NORTH OF THE RAINBOW ARCH BRIDGE.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 50 FEET NORTH OF THE TIP OF THE POINT AND ONE - HALF BLOCK NORTH OF THE INTERSECTION OF JOHN STREET, NIAGARA FALLS, ONT, WITH RIVER ROAD.  IT IS ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF AND THE STONE WALL ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF RIVER ROAD AND ABOUT 12 FEET EAST OF A DOUBLE TREE, THE LARGEST TREE ON THE POINT.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET NEARLY FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 1 FOOT IN DIAMETER AND 1 FOOT IN DEPTH.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRASS SCREW CEMENTED 1 FOOT UNDERGROUND IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE BEDROCK.  THERE ARE THREE REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS A DRILL HOLE 1 INCH IN DIAMETER AND 1-1/2 INCHES IN DEPTH IN THE TOP OF A LARGE BOULDER SHOWING A TRIANGULAR SURFACE ABOUT 30 INCHES ON A SIDE.  THE EAST SIDE OF THE BOULDER IS ABOUT 18 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND AND THE WEST SIDE IS ABOUT FLUSH.  THE BOULDER IS 6 FEET EAST OF THE WALL AND 7 FEET NORTH OF THE DOUBLE TREE.  NO 2 IS AN IRON POST 3 FEET EAST OF THE WALL AND 12 FEET SOUTH OF THE TREE.  MOUNTED ON THE POST IS A SIGN READING---KINGS HIGHWAY NO. 8---.  NO 3 IS A DRILL HOLE 1 INCH IN DIAMETER AND 1 INCH IN DEPTH IN A ROCK SHOWING AN AREA ABOUT 1 FOOT SQUARE, FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  THE ROCK IS ABOUT 8 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  TUG IWC NOT MARKED.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) THE STATION AND REFERENCE NO 1 WERE RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE NO 2 WAS NOT RECOVERED.  LIGHT POLE NO 1504 IS 62.5 FEET NORTH OF THE STATION AND LIGHT POLE NO 1518 IS 42.7 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE STATION.  THE STATION IS 24 FEET EAST OF THE WALL ALONG A SIDEWALK AND 18 FEET EAST OF A STEEL, WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1944 (NWS) ON THE EXTREME S END OF SAND ISLAND, ON THE HIGH ROAD EMBANKMENT, 70.55 FEET FROM THE NW CORNER OF THE W ABUTMENT OF THE HIGHWAY BRIDGE OVER THE ENTRACE TO ECHO BAY, AND 23.45 FEET FROM THE CENTER LINE OF THE CONCRETE HIGHWAY.  IT IS 27 FEET N OF THE TOWNSHIP OF MACDONALDS SIGNPOST.  IT IS AT THE TOP OF THE ROAD EMBANKMENT, 10 FEET ABOVE THE WATER IN LAKE GEORGE, AND 3 FEET OUTSIDE THE STEEL - CABLE FENCE ON THE W SIDE OF THE ROAD.  STATION MARK IS A 1/2-INCH DRILL HOLE IN A LARGE FLAT ROCK BURIED 2 FEET UNDERGROUND.  A STANDARD I B C BRONZE DISK IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE, 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER BY 20 INCHES LONG, IS SET OVER THE STATION, PROJECTING 2 INCHES WITH ROCKS PILED AROUND IT. THE STATION IS IN A HAY FIELD, ABOUT 14 METERS WEST OF A SECTION - LINE FENCE AND 73 METERS SOUTH OF THE FENCE CORNER.  IT IS ABOUT 4 METERS ABOVE AND 41 METERS BACK FROM THE RIVERS EDGE.  STATION MARK--NO SURFACE MARK.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A STONE AND A BALL OF WIRE.

IT IS 13 FEET S OF CENTER OF E - AND - W ROAD, 36.5 FEET SSE OF CORNER FENCE POST, 81 FEET SW OF CORNER FENCE POST ON E SIDE OF N - AND - S ROAD, AND 6 FEET W OF CENTER LINE OF THIS ROAD.  STATION MRK IS A STANDARD I B C BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK IN A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE, 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 20 INCHES LONG, SET FLUSH WITH SURFACE OF GROUND.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A ROUND - HEADED COPPER RIVET IN A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE, 7 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 10 INCHES LONG, SET 2 FEET UNDERGROUND. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY ONTARIO POWER GENERATION 2008 THE MARK IS LOCATED ABOUT 3.05 MI (4.9 KM) WEST OF CORNWALL, ONT., 1.23 MI (2.0 KM) NORTH NORTHEAST OF SAUNDERS DAM OWNERSHIP ONTARIO POWER GENERATION. CONTACT THE ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT AT 613-932-3072 TO OBTAIN PERMISSION TO ACCESS THE MARK.   TO REACH FROM THE INTERSECTION OF SECOND STREET AND POWER DAM DRIVE IN CORNWALL, ONT, TRAVEL WEST ON SECOND STREET FOR 0.96 MI (1.5 KM) TO A GATE, PASS THROUGH GATE AND TRAVEL NORTH ON ROAD FOR 0.84 MI (1.4 KM) TO THE MARK ON THE LEFT.   THE MARK IS THE TOP OF A 4 INCH (10 CM) U BOLT WELDED TO A STEEL FLOOD CONTROL GATE MARKED WEIR 4, PROJECTING 4 INCHES (10 CM) ABOVE FLOOD CONTROL GATE.

STATION MARK--A CROSS CUT IN A STONE.  SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BALL OF WIRE.
